It should be noted that strictly achieving the accuracy parity can sometimes require sacrifice in the average performance.
This is aligned with the result of Reddit dataset in TableÂ 6, where FedMGDAÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2022) achieved the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, while its average performance is only 10.58 in TableÂ 3.
This is far lower than our proposed methodâ€™s average performance, 12.95.
Except this case, AAggFF consistently shows the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG} than other baseline methods,
which is important in the perspective of striking a good balance between overall utility and the client-level fairness.

We conduct experiments on datasets mirroring realistic scenarios in FL systems:
multiple modalities (vision, text, speech, and tabular form) and natural data partitioning.

For the cross-silo setting,

For the cross-device setting,
we used CelebA vision dataset (Liu etÂ al., 2015),
Reddit text dataset (both are parts of LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019))
and SpeechCommands audio dataset (Warden, 2018).

With a relaxation of the original concept, we adopt the notion of accuracy parity for measuring the degree of the client-level fairness in the federated system, i.e., we simply regard the group as each client.
As a metric, we adopt the accuracy parity gap (Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}) proposed byÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2019; Chi etÂ al., 2021), which is simply defined as an absolute difference between the performance of the best and the worst performing groups (clients).
The results are in TableÂ 5 and TableÂ 6.
It can be said that the smaller the Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, the more degree of the accuracy parity fairness (and therefore the client-level fairness) is achieved.

For the verification, we test with two more datasets, Heart (Janosi etÂ al., 1988) and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015), each of which is suited for binary and multi-class classification (i.e., 200 classes in total).
Since the Heart dataset is a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022), it has pre-defined K=4ğ¾4K=4 clients.
For the TinyImageNet dataset, we simulate statistical heterogeneity for K=1,000ğ¾1000K=1,000 clients using Dirichlet distribution with a concentration of 0.010.010.01, following (Hsu etÂ al., 2019).
The results are in TableÂ 7, where the upper cell represents the performance of a naive FL algorithm,
and the lower cell contains a performance of the FL algorithm with AAggFF.
While the average performance remains comparable, the worst performance is consistently boosted in both cross-silo and cross-device settings.
This underpins the efficacy and flexibility of AAggFF, which can strengthen the fairness perspective of existing FL algorithms.

A2.T1.caption: Table A1: Example: Effects of CDF Transformations
references:
This is widely known as EGÂ (Helmbold etÂ al., 1998), a special realization of OMDÂ (Nemirovskij & Yudin, 1983; Warmuth etÂ al., 1997; Beck & Teboulle, 2003).
We summarize how existing methods can be unified under this OCO framework in TableÂ 1.
The detailed derivations of mixing coefficients from each method are provided in AppendixÂ A.1.

To sum up, we can interpret the aggregation mechanism in FL is secretly a result of the serverâ€™s sequential decision making behind the scene.
Since the sequential learning scheme is well-behaved in a sample-deficient setting,
adopting OCO is surely a suitable tactic for the server in that only a few bits are provided to update the mixing coefficients in each FL round, e.g, the number of local responses collected from the clients is at most Kğ¾K.
However, existing methods have not been devised with sequential decision making in mind.
Therefore, one can easily find suboptimal designs inherent in existing methods from an OCO perspective.
From the RemarkÂ 3.1 and TableÂ 1, one can easily notice suboptimal designs of existing methods in terms of OCO, as follows.

From now on, all proofs are deferred to AppendixÂ A.2.
According to the LemmaÂ 4.1, the Lipschitz constant of the decision loss, Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty},
is dependent upon the range of a response vectorâ€™s element.
While from the unification result in TableÂ 1,
one can easily notice that the response is constructed from local losses collected in round tğ‘¡t,
Fiâ€‹(ğœ½(t))âˆˆâ„â‰¥0,iâˆˆ[K]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptâ„absent0ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0},i\in[K].

Note again that the larger mixing coefficient should be assigned for the larger local loss.
In such a perspective, using the CDF for transforming a loss value is an acceptable approach
in that the CDF value is a good indicator for estimating â€œhow large a specific local loss isâ€,
relative to local losses from other clients.
To instill the comparative nature, local losses are divided by the average of observed losses in time tğ‘¡t
before applying the transformation.
As a result, all local losses are centered on 1 in expectation.
See AppendixÂ B.1 for detailed discussions.

From the TheoremÂ 5.1, we can enjoy ğ’ªâ€‹(Lâˆâ€‹Kâ€‹logâ¡T)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}K\log{T}\right) regret upper bound,
which is an acceptable result, considering a typical assumption in the cross-silo setting (i.e., K<Tğ¾ğ‘‡K<T).

We conduct experiments on datasets mirroring realistic scenarios in FL systems:
multiple modalities (vision, text, speech, and tabular form) and natural data partitioning.
We briefly summarize FL settings of each dataset in TableÂ 4.
For the cross-silo setting,
we used Berka tabular dataset (Berka, 1999),
MQP clinical text dataset (McCreery etÂ al., 2020),
and ISIC oncological image dataset (Codella etÂ al., 2018) (also a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022)).
For the cross-device setting,
we used CelebA vision dataset (Liu etÂ al., 2015),
Reddit text dataset (both are parts of LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019))
and SpeechCommands audio dataset (Warden, 2018).

In the cross-silo setting, we assume all Kğ¾K clients participate in Tğ‘‡T federation rounds (i.e., C=1ğ¶1C=1),
and in the cross-device setting, the client participation rate Câˆˆ(0,1)ğ¶01C\in(0,1) is set to ensure 555 among Kğ¾K clients are participating in each round.
We evaluate each dataset using appropriate metrics for tasks as indicated under the dataset name in TableÂ 2 andÂ 3, where the average, the best (10%), the worst (10%), and Gini coefficient222The Gini coefficient is inflated by (Ã—102absentsuperscript102\times 10^{2}) for readability. of clientsâ€™ performance distributions are reported with the standard deviation inside parentheses in gray color below the averaged metric.

With a relaxation of the original concept, we adopt the notion of accuracy parity for measuring the degree of the client-level fairness in the federated system, i.e., we simply regard the group as each client.
As a metric, we adopt the accuracy parity gap (Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}) proposed byÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2019; Chi etÂ al., 2021), which is simply defined as an absolute difference between the performance of the best and the worst performing groups (clients).
The results are in TableÂ 5 and TableÂ 6.
It can be said that the smaller the Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, the more degree of the accuracy parity fairness (and therefore the client-level fairness) is achieved.

It should be noted that strictly achieving the accuracy parity can sometimes require sacrifice in the average performance.
This is aligned with the result of Reddit dataset in TableÂ 6, where FedMGDAÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2022) achieved the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, while its average performance is only 10.58 in TableÂ 3.
This is far lower than our proposed methodâ€™s average performance, 12.95.
Except this case, AAggFF consistently shows the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG} than other baseline methods,
which is important in the perspective of striking a good balance between overall utility and the client-level fairness.

For the verification, we test with two more datasets, Heart (Janosi etÂ al., 1988) and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015), each of which is suited for binary and multi-class classification (i.e., 200 classes in total).
Since the Heart dataset is a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022), it has pre-defined K=4ğ¾4K=4 clients.
For the TinyImageNet dataset, we simulate statistical heterogeneity for K=1,000ğ¾1000K=1,000 clients using Dirichlet distribution with a concentration of 0.010.010.01, following (Hsu etÂ al., 2019).
The results are in TableÂ 7, where the upper cell represents the performance of a naive FL algorithm,
and the lower cell contains a performance of the FL algorithm with AAggFF.
While the average performance remains comparable, the worst performance is consistently boosted in both cross-silo and cross-device settings.
This underpins the efficacy and flexibility of AAggFF, which can strengthen the fairness perspective of existing FL algorithms.

For improving the degree of the client-level fairness in FL,
we first reveal the connection of existing fair FL methods with the OCO.
To emphasize the sequential decision making perspective, we propose improved designs and further specialize them into two practical settings: cross-silo FL & cross-device FL.
Our framework not only efficiently enhances a low-performing group of clients compared to existing baselines,
but also maintains an acceptable average performance with theoretically guaranteed behaviors.
It should also be noted that AAggFF requires no extra communication and no added local computation,
which are significant constraints for serving FL-based services.
With this scalability, our method can also improve the fairness of the performance distributions of existing FL algorithms without much modification to their original mechanism.
By explicitly bringing the sequential decision making scheme to the front,
we expect our work to open up new designs to promote the practicality and scalability of FL.

Suppose we have K=3ğ¾3K=3 local losses: F1â€‹(ğœ½)=0.01,F2â€‹(ğœ½)=0.10,F3â€‹(ğœ½)=0.02formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹1ğœ½0.01formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹2ğœ½0.10subscriptğ¹3ğœ½0.02F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.01,F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.10,F_{3}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.02.
Since the average is FÂ¯=0.01+0.10+0.023â‰ˆ0.043Â¯F0.010.100.0230.043\bar{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{0.01+0.10+0.02}{3}\approx 0.043, we have inputs of CDF as follows: F1â€‹(ğœ½)/FÂ¯=0.23,F2â€‹(ğœ½)/FÂ¯=2.31,F3â€‹(ğœ½)/FÂ¯=0.46formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹1ğœ½Â¯F0.23formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹2ğœ½Â¯F2.31subscriptğ¹3ğœ½Â¯F0.46F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=0.23,F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=2.31,F_{3}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=0.46.
These centered inputs are finally transformed into bounded values as in TableÂ A1.

While all losses become bounded values in [0,1]01[0,1], the maximum local loss (i.e., F2â€‹(ğœ½)=0.10subscriptğ¹2ğœ½0.10F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.10) is transformed into different values by each CDF (see underlined figures in the â€˜Transformed Responsesâ€™ column of TableÂ A1).
When using the Weibull CDF, the maximum local loss is translated into 1.001.001.00, which means that there may be no value greater than 0.10 (i.e., 0.100.100.10 is the largest one in 100%percent100100\% probability) given current local losses.
Meanwhile, when using the Frechet CDF, the maximum local loss is translated into 0.650.650.65, which means that there still is a 35% chance that some other local losses are greater than 0.100.100.10 when provided with other losses similar to 0.01 and 0.02.
This implies that each CDF treats a maximum value differently.
When a transformation is easily inclined to the maximum value, thereby returning 1 (i.e., maximum of CDF), it may yield a degenerate decision, e.g., ğ’‘â‰ˆ[0,1,0]âŠ¤ğ’‘superscript010top\boldsymbol{p}\approx[0,1,0]^{\top}.

In the cross-silo experiment with the Berka dataset, the Normal CDF shows the smallest cumulative values,
while in the cross-device experiment with the Reddit dataset, the Weibull CDF yields the smallest value.
For the Berka dataset, the Normal CDF yields an average performance (AUROC) of 79.37 with the worst performance of 43.75,
but the Weibull CDF shows an average performance of 73.02 with the worst performance of 25.00.
The same tendency is also observed in the Reddit dataset.
The Normal CDF presents an average performance (Acc. 1) of 14.05 and the worst performance of 4.26,
while the Weibull CDF shows an average of 12.62 with the worst of 3.35.
From these observations, we can conclude that an appropriate choice of CDF is necessary for better sequential decision making, and suitable transformation helps minimize a global objective of FL.
Note also that these behaviors are also directly related to the global convergence of the algorithm w.r.t. ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}.

For the main experiments in TableÂ 2 and TableÂ 3,
we used 3 datasets for the cross-silo setting (Berka (Berka, 1999), MQP (McCreery etÂ al., 2020), and ISIC (Codella etÂ al., 2018; OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022)),
and 3 other datasets for the cross-device setting (CelebA, Reddit (Caldas etÂ al., 2019), and SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018)).
In this section, we describe details of each dataset about its task, metrics, and client partitioning.
The statistics of all federated benchmarks are summarized in TableÂ A2.
Note that Avg. and Std. in the table refer to the average and a standard deviation of a sample size of each client in the FL system

Berka is a tabular dataset containing bank transaction records collected from Czech bank (Berka, 1999).
Berka accompanies the loan default prediction task (i.e., binary classification) of each bankâ€™s customers.
It is fully anonymized and is originally composed of 8 relational tables: accounts, clients, disposition, loans, permanent orders, transactions, demographics, and credit cards.
We merged all 8 tables into one dataset by joining the primary keys of each table, and finally have 15 input features.
From the demographics table, we obtain information on the region: Prague, Central Bohemia, South Bohemia, West Bohemia, North Bohemia, East Bohemia, South Moravia, and North Moravia.
We split each client according to the region and excluded all samples of North Bohemia since it has only one record of loan default, thus we finally have 7 clients (i.e., banks).
Finally, we used the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve for the evaluation metric.

MQP is a clinical question pair dataset crawled from medical question answering dataset (Ben Abacha & Demner-Fushman, 2019),
and labeled by 11 doctors (McCreery etÂ al., 2020).
All paired sentences are labeled as either similar or dissimilar, thereby it is suitable for the binary classification task.
As a pre-processing, we merge two paired sentences into one sentence by adding special tokens: [SEP], [PAD], and [UNK].
We set the maximum token length to 200, thus merged sentences less than 200 are filled with [PAD] tokens, and otherwise are truncated. Then, merged sentences are tokenized using pre-trained DistilBERT tokenizer (Sanh etÂ al., 2019).
We regard each doctor as a separate client and thus have 11 clients.
Finally, we used the area under the ROC curve for the evaluation metric.

references:
This is widely known as EGÂ (Helmbold etÂ al., 1998), a special realization of OMDÂ (Nemirovskij & Yudin, 1983; Warmuth etÂ al., 1997; Beck & Teboulle, 2003).
We summarize how existing methods can be unified under this OCO framework in TableÂ 1.
The detailed derivations of mixing coefficients from each method are provided in AppendixÂ A.1.

To sum up, we can interpret the aggregation mechanism in FL is secretly a result of the serverâ€™s sequential decision making behind the scene.
Since the sequential learning scheme is well-behaved in a sample-deficient setting,
adopting OCO is surely a suitable tactic for the server in that only a few bits are provided to update the mixing coefficients in each FL round, e.g, the number of local responses collected from the clients is at most Kğ¾K.
However, existing methods have not been devised with sequential decision making in mind.
Therefore, one can easily find suboptimal designs inherent in existing methods from an OCO perspective.
From the RemarkÂ 3.1 and TableÂ 1, one can easily notice suboptimal designs of existing methods in terms of OCO, as follows.

From now on, all proofs are deferred to AppendixÂ A.2.
According to the LemmaÂ 4.1, the Lipschitz constant of the decision loss, Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty},
is dependent upon the range of a response vectorâ€™s element.
While from the unification result in TableÂ 1,
one can easily notice that the response is constructed from local losses collected in round tğ‘¡t,
Fiâ€‹(ğœ½(t))âˆˆâ„â‰¥0,iâˆˆ[K]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptâ„absent0ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0},i\in[K].

Note again that the larger mixing coefficient should be assigned for the larger local loss.
In such a perspective, using the CDF for transforming a loss value is an acceptable approach
in that the CDF value is a good indicator for estimating â€œhow large a specific local loss isâ€,
relative to local losses from other clients.
To instill the comparative nature, local losses are divided by the average of observed losses in time tğ‘¡t
before applying the transformation.
As a result, all local losses are centered on 1 in expectation.
See AppendixÂ B.1 for detailed discussions.

From the TheoremÂ 5.1, we can enjoy ğ’ªâ€‹(Lâˆâ€‹Kâ€‹logâ¡T)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}K\log{T}\right) regret upper bound,
which is an acceptable result, considering a typical assumption in the cross-silo setting (i.e., K<Tğ¾ğ‘‡K<T).

We conduct experiments on datasets mirroring realistic scenarios in FL systems:
multiple modalities (vision, text, speech, and tabular form) and natural data partitioning.
We briefly summarize FL settings of each dataset in TableÂ 4.
For the cross-silo setting,
we used Berka tabular dataset (Berka, 1999),
MQP clinical text dataset (McCreery etÂ al., 2020),
and ISIC oncological image dataset (Codella etÂ al., 2018) (also a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022)).
For the cross-device setting,
we used CelebA vision dataset (Liu etÂ al., 2015),
Reddit text dataset (both are parts of LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019))
and SpeechCommands audio dataset (Warden, 2018).

In the cross-silo setting, we assume all Kğ¾K clients participate in Tğ‘‡T federation rounds (i.e., C=1ğ¶1C=1),
and in the cross-device setting, the client participation rate Câˆˆ(0,1)ğ¶01C\in(0,1) is set to ensure 555 among Kğ¾K clients are participating in each round.
We evaluate each dataset using appropriate metrics for tasks as indicated under the dataset name in TableÂ 2 andÂ 3, where the average, the best (10%), the worst (10%), and Gini coefficient222The Gini coefficient is inflated by (Ã—102absentsuperscript102\times 10^{2}) for readability. of clientsâ€™ performance distributions are reported with the standard deviation inside parentheses in gray color below the averaged metric.

With a relaxation of the original concept, we adopt the notion of accuracy parity for measuring the degree of the client-level fairness in the federated system, i.e., we simply regard the group as each client.
As a metric, we adopt the accuracy parity gap (Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}) proposed byÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2019; Chi etÂ al., 2021), which is simply defined as an absolute difference between the performance of the best and the worst performing groups (clients).
The results are in TableÂ 5 and TableÂ 6.
It can be said that the smaller the Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, the more degree of the accuracy parity fairness (and therefore the client-level fairness) is achieved.

It should be noted that strictly achieving the accuracy parity can sometimes require sacrifice in the average performance.
This is aligned with the result of Reddit dataset in TableÂ 6, where FedMGDAÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2022) achieved the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, while its average performance is only 10.58 in TableÂ 3.
This is far lower than our proposed methodâ€™s average performance, 12.95.
Except this case, AAggFF consistently shows the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG} than other baseline methods,
which is important in the perspective of striking a good balance between overall utility and the client-level fairness.

For the verification, we test with two more datasets, Heart (Janosi etÂ al., 1988) and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015), each of which is suited for binary and multi-class classification (i.e., 200 classes in total).
Since the Heart dataset is a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022), it has pre-defined K=4ğ¾4K=4 clients.
For the TinyImageNet dataset, we simulate statistical heterogeneity for K=1,000ğ¾1000K=1,000 clients using Dirichlet distribution with a concentration of 0.010.010.01, following (Hsu etÂ al., 2019).
The results are in TableÂ 7, where the upper cell represents the performance of a naive FL algorithm,
and the lower cell contains a performance of the FL algorithm with AAggFF.
While the average performance remains comparable, the worst performance is consistently boosted in both cross-silo and cross-device settings.
This underpins the efficacy and flexibility of AAggFF, which can strengthen the fairness perspective of existing FL algorithms.

For improving the degree of the client-level fairness in FL,
we first reveal the connection of existing fair FL methods with the OCO.
To emphasize the sequential decision making perspective, we propose improved designs and further specialize them into two practical settings: cross-silo FL & cross-device FL.
Our framework not only efficiently enhances a low-performing group of clients compared to existing baselines,
but also maintains an acceptable average performance with theoretically guaranteed behaviors.
It should also be noted that AAggFF requires no extra communication and no added local computation,
which are significant constraints for serving FL-based services.
With this scalability, our method can also improve the fairness of the performance distributions of existing FL algorithms without much modification to their original mechanism.
By explicitly bringing the sequential decision making scheme to the front,
we expect our work to open up new designs to promote the practicality and scalability of FL.

For the main experiments in TableÂ 2 and TableÂ 3,
we used 3 datasets for the cross-silo setting (Berka (Berka, 1999), MQP (McCreery etÂ al., 2020), and ISIC (Codella etÂ al., 2018; OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022)),
and 3 other datasets for the cross-device setting (CelebA, Reddit (Caldas etÂ al., 2019), and SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018)).

Berka is a tabular dataset containing bank transaction records collected from Czech bank (Berka, 1999).
